title: Istanbul International Music Festival
text:
The Istanbul International Music Festival, formerly Istanbul Festival, () is a cultural event held every June and July in <a href="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>, <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>. It offers a selection of <a href="European%20classical%20music">European classical music</a>, <a href="ballet">ballet</a>, <a href="opera">opera</a> and <a href="traditional%20music">traditional music</a> performances with the participations of famous artists from all over the world. The festival was first held in 1973 and is organized by the Istanbul Foundation of Culture and Arts. In 2006, <a href="Borusan">Borusan Holding</a> took over its main sponsorship from <a href="Eczac%C4%B1ba%C5%9F%C4%B1">Eczacıbaşı Holding</a>.
The festival was the idea of the late Turkish businessman Dr. <a href="Nejat%20Eczac%C4%B1ba%C5%9F%C4%B1">Nejat Eczacıbaşı</a>. The first Istanbul Festival was held from June 15 to July 15, 1973, on the 50th anniversary of the foundation of the <a href="Republic%20of%20Turkey">Republic of Turkey</a>. From its first inception, the Istanbul Festival has aimed at including in its programs the finest examples of artistic creativity in all disciplines of art from both Turkey and abroad, as well as seminars, conferences and lectures. So, other festivals dedicated to <a href="film">film</a> (1984), <a href="jazz">jazz</a> (1986), <a href="contemporary%20art">contemporary art</a> (1987) and <a href="theater">theater</a> (1989) were added to the program of Istanbul Festival. From 1994 on, the name was changed to Istanbul International Music Festival to distinguish it from the other sister festivals. It is accredited as a member of <a href="European%20Festivals%20Association">European Festivals Association</a> since 1977. In 2014, a project title "Istanbul Music Festival Seeks Its Young Solist" () was started to promote talented young musicians.
From its beginning, the festival hosted world-renowned artists and groups from <a href="La%20Scala">La Scala Philharmonic</a> (<a href="Riccardo%20Muti">Riccardo Muti</a>), <a href="New%20York%20Philharmonic">New York Philharmonic</a> (<a href="Kurt%20Masur">Kurt Masur</a> and <a href="Zubin%20Mehta">Zubin Mehta</a>), <a href="Berlin%20Philharmonic">Berlin Philharmonic</a> to <a href="Royal%20Concertgebouw%20Orchestra">Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra</a> (<a href="Wolfgang%20Sawallisch">Wolfgang Sawallisch</a>), <a href="Dresden%20Staatskapelle">Dresden Staatskapelle</a> and the soloists, orchestra and chorus of the <a href="Mariinsky%20Theatre">Mariinsky Theatre</a> (<a href="Kirov%20Opera">Kirov Opera</a>), from <a href="Orpheus%20Chamber%20Orchestra">Orpheus Chamber Orchestra</a> (<a href="Gidon%20Kremer">Gidon Kremer</a>) to <a href="Scottish%20Chamber%20Orchestra">Scottish Chamber Orchestra</a> (<a href="Charles%20Mackerras">Charles Mackerras</a> and <a href="Richard%20Hickox">Richard Hickox</a>), from <a href="Tokyo%20String%20Quartet">Tokyo String Quartet</a> to <a href="Hilliard%20Ensemble">Hilliard Ensemble</a>, from <a href="Aldo%20Ciccolini">Aldo Ciccolini</a> to <a href="Ivo%20Pogorelich">Ivo Pogorelich</a>, from <a href="Yehudi%20Menuhin">Yehudi Menuhin</a> to <a href="Itzhak%20Perlman">Itzhak Perlman</a>, from <a href="Julian%20Lloyd%20Webber">Julian Lloyd Webber</a> to <a href="Mischa%20Maisky">Mischa Maisky</a>, from <a href="Narciso%20Yepes">Narciso Yepes</a> to <a href="Christopher%20Parkening">Christopher Parkening</a>, from <a href="Leyla%20Gencer">Leyla Gencer</a> to <a href="Montserrat%20Caball%C3%A9">Montserrat Caballé</a> and <a href="Elisabeth%20Schwarzkopf">Elisabeth Schwarzkopf</a>, from <a href="Bolshoi%20Ballet">Bolshoi Ballet</a> to <a href="American%20Ballet%20Theatre">American Ballet Theatre</a> and to <a href="Mark%20Morris%20%28choreographer%29">Mark Morris</a>, <a href="Mehmet%20Sander">Mehmet Sander</a>, <a href="Kibbutz%20dance%20companies">Kibbutz dance companies</a>; and such traditional music groups as <a href="Istanbul%20Oriental%20Ensemble">Istanbul Oriental Ensemble</a> of <a href="Burhan%20%C3%96%C3%A7al">Burhan Öçal</a>, <a href="Kudsi%20Erg%C3%BCner">Kudsi Ergüner</a>’s Tac Mahal project and <a href="Whirling%20Dervishes">Whirling Dervishes</a>. The 31st festival saw the prominent conductor <a href="Lorin%20Maazel">Lorin Maazel</a> with the <a href="Bavarian%20Radio%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra</a> and a legend of the music world, <a href="Cecilia%20Bartoli">Cecilia Bartoli</a>, who received an enthusiastic standing ovation from the audience for several minutes.
The festival venues include <a href="Galata%20Mevlevihanesi">Galata Mevlevihanesi</a>, <a href="Istanbul%20University">Istanbul University</a> Rectorate Building, <a href="Istanbul%20Modern">Istanbul Modern</a> and <a href="Silahtara%C4%9Fa%20Power%20Station%23The%20Energy%20Museum%20at%20Santral%C4%B0stanbul">Santralistanbul Energy Museum</a>, <a href="Zorlu%20Center%20PSM">Zorlu Center PSM</a> and <a href="Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i%20University">Boğaziçi University</a> Albert Long Hall in addition the <a href="Hagia%20Irene">Hagia Eirene Museum</a>, <a href="Istanbul%20Archaeology%20Museums">Archaeological Museum</a>, <a href="Tiled%20Kiosk">Tiled Kiosk</a>, <a href="S%C3%BCreyya%20Opera%20House">Süreyya Opera House</a> and <a href="Istanbul%20L%C3%BCtfi%20K%C4%B1rdar%20Convention%20and%20Exhibition%20Center">Lütfi Kırdar Convention and Exhibition Center</a>.
According to a famed international musicologist, the Festival bridges cultural and religious divisions.
